qas.question: How can a wrestler be disqualified?

answers.text: wrestler violates the match's rules, thus losing automatically

qas.question: In what case can a countout and disqualification be done away with entirely?

answers.text: must be declared a "no holds barred" match, a "street fight" or some other term

context: Disqualification (sometimes abbreviated as "<a0_0>DQ<a0_0/>") occurs when a <a1_0>wrestler violates the match's rules, thus losing automatically<a1_0/>. Although a countout can technically be considered a disqualification (as it is, for all intents and purposes, an automatic loss suffered as a result of violating a match rule), the two concepts are often distinct in wrestling. A no disqualification match can still end by countout (although this is rare); typically, a match <a2_0>must be declared a "no holds barred" match, a "street fight" or some other term<a2_0/>, in order for both disqualifications and countouts to be waived.[citation needed]
